div.p: MS 2206 Ellis Rowan papers, National Library, Canberra.

Yesterday, dear Madam, I wrote you a long letter
M to E. Rowan, 1 December 1895. in answer to your cheering communication written on the last Columbus-Day (12. Oct),
Letter not found. in which I endeavoured to convey, how touched I was by the generous expressions, which her Majesty condescended to bestow on my humble studies. The letter was hurriedly despatched, adressed according to your last letter 16 Hackin [...]
illegible.
West. But in searching for your letter written on the "Austral" in March,
Letter not found. I find that your standing adress is Bank of N.S.W Old Broad Street.

The full letter is registered and if you do not receive it soon after this letter, will you kindly enquire for it? I invoked your kind and patriotic aid for obtaining Lord Scotts
Check this – Loch? Check with previous letter and below.
influence to get the plan for renewed antarctic researches further considered by the Admiralty. It would require only 2 of the older steamships of the Royal Navy for a year or two, and thus with Steam-power nothing like the expenditure for the Expedition by Sir James Ross in Sailing ships only would be incurred. I pointed out that I communicated on my own impulses with Lord Loch, when he was Governor of South Africa, as Enderby-Land is comparative near thereto for a basis of operation, with water open far south seen thence. The Cape-Ministry was not unfavorable and would therefore likely contribute to such an expedition Could you kindly see Lord Loch, who might influence Mr Goeshen and his Admiralty Lords, especially as great whaling and sealing interests would also have to be considered. The idea of Britain being forestalled or even excluded from this promising glorious work seems impossible. Sir Jos. Hooker, as pres. of the British Committee, Admiral Ommaney as Hon Sectry Admiral Sir George Richards as former Hydrographer, Admiral Nares, who was to the antarctic circle,
Nares commanded HMS Challebger during its voyage of oceanographical research in 187?
Sir Henry Barkly as a former Australian Governor would be sure to help so Mr Markham, the Presid of the royal geogr Soc.

div.p: Are you acquainted with any members of Mr Goeshens family. My name is not unknown to the Right Hon Gentleman. How we also here would rejoyce if a British Expedition could operate in the south-polar ocean already in the summer 1896-1897.
